users.title: For Users
body: Bitcoin is a worldwide peer-to-peer electronic cash system, known for low and predictable transaction fees, reliable confirmation times, and useable instant transactions. Unfortunately, because many network nodes continue to enforce a limit on the size of blocks which is below today's demand (the current limit corresponds to roughly 3 transactions per second), fees have risen, backlogs of transactions have formed, and confirmation times have become erratic. A smaller number of nodes have even adopted replace-by-fee policies to permit double-spending of transactions stuck due to the backlogs, which has produced the regrettable side effect of making instant Bitcoin transactions less secure.

By supporting Bitcoin Unlimited, you are supporting our organization's efforts to reduce transaction fees and confirmation times by enabling node operators to lift their block size limits, as well as our efforts to reverse the damage done to instant transactions through the misguided replace-by-fee initiative.

nodes.title: For Node Operators
body: Bigger blocks are coming. When they arrive, you want your node to be ready. Whether your node powers a Bitcoin business or your own wallet, the Bitcoin Unlimited client allows you to securely track consensus as defined by the most proof-of-work chain composed of valid transactions, regardless of the outcome of the "block size limit debate".

The Bitcoin Unlimited client is designed around the principle that Bitcoin should evolve through a bottom-up, free-market-based process where your voice as a node operator can be heard. Using the client's graphical user interface, you can easily adjust your node's block size limit, to signal to miners that you are ready for bigger blocks today.

As Bitcoin continues to grow its user base, the resources required to run a node likewise increase. Bitcoin Unlimited developers are focused on removing bottlenecks to counteract this effect. Bitcoin Unlimited was the first client to solve the "block propagation bottleneck" identified by Cornell researchers in 2016 as the dominant bottleneck to increasing network throughput. Our solution—known as Xtreme Thin Blocks—reduced block propagation times by a factor of 5.6x across the normal P2P network and by a factor of 8.7x across the Great Firewall of China, while using 24x fewer bytes. Bitcoin Unlimited developers followed this up with their latest innovation called Parallel Validation, which further improves the efficiency of the BU client.
Switching to Bitcoin Unlimited from another Satoshi-client is as simple as downloading and installing the software. There is no need to re-download the blockchain.

miners.title: For Miners
body: Say "no" to production quotas and central planning of the block space market. If there is demand for block space, as a miner you should be free to meet that demand. By running Bitcoin Unlimited, you are literally casting a vote in your coinbase transaction for a free market in block space, and thus a vote to continue growing Bitcoin in the most simple and proven manner: with more on-chain transactions.

Watch the block size preference of the network evolve by examining the block-size limit settings of network nodes (expressed in the user-agent string) and other miners (expressed in the coinbase transactions), ensuring that you always have up-to-date information regarding how big you can safely make your blocks.

But Bitcoin Unlimited is not just about a free market in block space. Bitcoin Unlimited's Xpedited block relay (based on Xthin technology) ensures that you're always mining on the latest block and that the blocks you solve propagate across the network quickly regardless of their size, thereby increasing your profitability. With Parallel Validation, your node will no longer by locked up while validating new blocks, but free to do other useful things instead.

Bitcoin Unlimited developers are continuously working with progressive miners like you to ensure that the features you need to be successful are included in our software. If you would like to get involved in this process, please feel free to contact us.

investors.title: For Investors
body: To bootstrap this new digital currency, it takes investors like you willing to hold bitcoin through the ups and downs of its price action. You want to be rewarded for that risk. By supporting Bitcoin Unlimited you are supporting our objective to return control over Bitcoin's evolution back to the market and our efforts to enable node operators to lift the block size limit that is presently restricting transaction volumes. By removing this limit, Bitcoin's user base will be free to grow, and with it its market capitalization.

technologies.title: Technologies
technologies.subtitle: Bitcoin Unlimited powers the backbone of the Bitcoin network by using novel technologies.

adjustableCap.title: Adjustable Block-size Cap (ABC)
body: Bitcoin Unlimited was the first client to provide the tools that node operators and miners need to remove the 1 MB block size limit currently limiting transaction throughput on the Bitcoin network. The BU client allows node operators to easily adjust the size of blocks their node accepts, without having to restart their node or recompile new executables from source code. Similarly, BU allows miners to begin producing larger blocks without a restart or a recompile. BU provides both groups the ability to signal their block size preferences across the network, using the user-agent string in the case of common nodes, and using the coinbase transaction of each new block in the case of mining nodes.

xthin.title: Xtreme Thin Blocks (Xthin)
body: Bitcoin Unlimited was the first client to fix the inefficiency in the core Bitcoin code that resulted in transactions often being received twice by each node: once when the transaction was first broadcast by a user to the peer-to-peer network, and again when a solved block containing the now-confirmed transaction was found by a miner.

Rather than requesting the block verbatim, an Xthin-equipped node images its mempool onto a Bloom filter that its sends with its "get data" request; the transmitting node sends the block contents by hash for all the transactions imaged onto the Bloom filter and in full otherwise. In the unlikely event that the receiving node is unable to reconstruct the block, it requests the still-missing transactions, resulting in a second round trip between the nodes.

parallelValidation.title: Parallel Validation
body: Prior to parallel validation, when a node received a new block, it would essentially freeze until it had either accepted or rejected the block in question. During this validation period, the node would neither relay new transactions nor attempt to validate competing blocks.
This resulted in an attack vector where a malicious entity could mine an extremely slow-to-verify block and temporarily freeze the network.

Parallel validation neutralizes this attack vector by allowing nodes to validate more than one block--along with new incoming transactions--all at the same time. This improves Bitcoin’s performance as a payment network because there is no longer any interruption in transaction processing during block validation. Furthermore, because a fast-to-validate block will "win" a block race against a slow-to-validate block found at the same time, the widespread adoption of parallel validation would add a cost of approximately 1.25 BTC per validation-minute due to the increased orphan risk of slow-to-verify blocks.

technical.title: Select Technical Works by Bitcoin Unlimited Members

space.body: In this paper, Dr. Peter R. Rizun shows that a transaction fee market exists without a block size limit, due to the increased risk a miner faces of having his block orphaned for each additional transaction he includes in his block. In the corresponding video, Rizun explains how block space has the properties of a normal economic commodity and satisfies the laws of supply and demand. He argues that the 1 MB block size limit is now acting as a "production quota," thereby resulting in a deadweight loss of economic activity in the Bitcoin economy.

In this paper, Bitcoin Unlimited lead developer G. Andrew Stone explores the mystery behind the "empty block" phenomenon and shows that empty blocks place a natural restriction on the rate at which the blockchain can grow.

propogation.body: Xthin is arguably the innovation that put Bitcoin Unlimited on the map. In this article series, Bitcoin Unlimited developers compare the performance of Xthin block propagation to standard block propagation. They show that Xthin blocks are 5.6x faster across the normal P2P network and cross the Great Firewall of China in 8.7x less time, both while using 24x fewer bytes.

In this article, Rizun explores a pre-consensus technique based on weak blocks. He shows how the technique permits larger blocks for a given level of orphan risk, diverts transaction fees to pay for hashing (blockchain security), and improves the security of unconfirmed transactions, all while maintaining the transaction fee market.

consensus.body: Bitcoin Unlimited empowers node operators to control how they enforce certain Bitcoin block validity rules on their own node. In this article, BU member Antony Zegers explores the market incentives facing node operators when they choose to enforce block validity rules, and how these incentives lead to an emergent consensus on the Bitcoin network.

In this video, Bitcoin Unlimited member John Swingle argues that "hard forks" should generally be preferred over "soft forks" because while the former increase user and market choice, the latter undermine user and market choice by increasing the coordination cost of resisting an unpopular or controversial change. Swingle further argues that in many cases, the added constraints of making a protocol change as a soft fork necessitate the introduction of additional and inherently-dangerous complexity.

bu.body: Bitcoin Unlimited's consensus layer is concerned with preserving the money property of Bitcoin. Using simple animations, Peter Rizun explains how a BU node deals with blocks that are potentially problematic to accept for technical (non-monetary) reasons.

nonTechnical.title: Select Non-technical Works by Bitcoin Unlimited Members

articles.body: Because Bitcoin has no center (it is decentralized), node operators must take matters into their own hands in order to create change. This article explains how Bitcoin Unlimited can be used as a tool to help create that change.

Bitcoin Unlimited does not constrain node operators or miners to one particular coordination scheme with regards to the block size limit; instead it is a tool that can be used to implement several different schemes. In this article, Bitcoin Unlimited member and ViaBTC Mining Pool CEO Haipo Yang proposes a way for miners to coordinate for the upcoming increase in the size of blocks.

Generally, a problem can rarely be solved unless it is properly recognized. Specifically, Bitcoin's centralized maximum block size is put into historical context and a decentralized solution is presented. This article introduces emergence, which is a fundamental aspect of nature giving rise to many levels of complexity. Further, its important and long-term applicability for determining the optimum block size limit in the Bitcoin network is shown.

faq.q1: Will unlimited size blocks actually result in no fee market?
faq.a1a: No. Intuitively you can understand this by realizing that it will take a lot longer to propagate a gigantic block across the network than a small one. Therefore a gigantic block has a higher likelihood of being "orphaned" -- that is, a competing block will be found, propagated across the network and supplant the gigantic block. In this case the miner of the gigantic block will lose the block subsidy and transaction fees. Therefore miners are incentivised by limitations in the underlying physical network to produce smaller blocks, and incentivized by transaction fees to produce larger ones.
faq.a1b: Finding the balance between these forces is where the free market excels. As underlying physical networks improve or fees increase, miners will naturally be able to produce larger blocks. The transaction "supply" (space in a block) therefore depends directly on the fundamental capacity, rather than relying on some centralized "steering committee" to properly set maximum block size. Bitcoin is all about disintermediation, and this is another example of it working.
faq.a1c: For a formal treatment of this subject see
faq.a1d: A Transaction Fee Market Exists Without a Block Size Limit
faq.q2: Will unlimited size blocks actually result in gigantic blocks?
faq.a2a: No. The effective network throughput is currently limited by the production of single transaction (empty except for the coinbase) blocks. The larger blocks get, the more of these blocks are generated, resulting in a maximum average block size. Additionally a rational miner should not accept a gigantic block since it denies him any chance to also produce transaction-containing blocks. More specifically, if the expected time to find and validate a short block is lower than the time to validate the gigantic block, it maximizes revenue to continue to mine a sibling while simultaneously validating the gigantic block.
faq.a2b: For a formal treatment of these subjects see
faq.a2c: An Examination of Single-Transaction Blocks and Their Effect on Network Throughput and Block Size
faq.q3: Why is a formal Bitcoin Unlimited Articles of Federation necessary?
faq.a3a: It is completely unknown whether the majority of Bitcoin users support a block size greater than 1 MB. No formal debate or vote has occurred. In contrast, debate is censored on the two most popular Bitcoin community sites.
faq.a3b: A majority of miners have "voted" for the unimplemented BIP100 proposal (this proposal would then allow miners to vote on block size), yet nothing has been done to implement BIP100. The existence of BIP100, BIP101 and other proposals may be "splitting" the large max-block community -- yet there is no known mechanism to authoritatively retire a proposal so the community can converge on a single proposal. As such, individuals who have contributed a vast amount of time and energy to a particular implementation/BIP find themselves without recourse as the power to add or remove features rests solely with individuals who possess technical skills and were at the right place at the right time.
faq.a3c: When you switch to the Bitcoin Unlimited client, the Articles of Federation will ensure that your voice is heard, and your vote counted.
faq.a3d: Proposals are made, debated, and then resolved (voted on) and the Proposer and BU officers have the power to force this process to occur in a timely fashion. The Articles also ensure that passed, implemented proposals are committed to the code repository in a timely fashion.
faq.a3e: For more information please read the
faq.q4: Is BU going to fork the Blockchain?
faq.a4a: No. But if some other entity causes a fork, if for example miners start producing > 1MB blocks, then Bitcoin Unlimited nodes will follow the most-work (generally the longest) fork. This means that your BU node will track the mining majority rather then a specific choice.
faq.a4b: Right now, the only event that will trigger this behavior is a block size fork because we believe that the block size is NOT part of blockchain consensus. If other events that are currently part of "consensus layer" should also trigger this behavior they may be added based on the outcome of a BUIP (Bitcoin Unlimited Implementation Proposal) submission, debate and vote.
faq.q5: Does BU open up a new Sybil attack vector? Say some entity launches thousands of nodes, 60,000 for example (100x the current network levels). Then sets a super small blocksize. Does this not end up holding the network hostage and thus also the blocksize cap?
faq.a5a: Nodes have this power and therefore the network is vulnerable to this kind of attack with or without BU. If you have the resources and desire to launch 60,000 nodes, a few changes to the source code will not put you off -- having access to BU is irrelevant.
faq.q6: Can miners run BU, select a very small block limit and therefore reduce transaction supply below 1MB?
faq.a6a: If 51% of the miners want smaller blocks they can have them today without BU. They can simply limit the size of their generated blocks -- the max mined block size is a command line option. Also, the max block size to accept is a constant defined in a header file. So 1 simple line of code needs to be changed for miners to ignore blocks bigger than N in all the "Satoshi-derived" clients.
faq.q7: Does BU affect blockchain consensus? Is it possible for a network filled with BU nodes to not converge?
faq.a7a: If you set certain parameters to certain values you can, for example, mimic the behavior of Bitcoin Core. Bitcoin Core will not converge in a network with miners producing blocks that are both greater than and less than 1 MB (this is called a fork).
faq.a7b: Let us imagine a BU-only network with the excessive block size set at 1 MB for many nodes, and blocks being produced at both less than 1MB and greater than 1MB. This network will converge rapidly if there is a large disparity in hash power between the two groups. The larger block nodes "sees" the smaller chain and will switch to it right away if it takes the lead. The smaller block group "sees" the larger chain but will resist switching to it until additional blocks have been built on top of it. So the smaller block group may always be a few blocks behind and small block miners will produce many orphans. The opposite is true in the case where large block miners are the hash power minority, except that they are always at the head of the most-work chain. This orphan production is feedback mechanism the network uses to the miners to change their behavior.
faq.a7c: If the two groups have approximately equal hashing power, the situation becomes a
faq.a7e: due to the fact that block production is a Poisson process. In this case, the mathematics show that one fork will periodically move far enough ahead of the other to trigger a convergence.
faq.a7f: If the network is undergoing a period of block size instability, whether that be due to a struggle between two block-size-is-part-of-consensus clients like XT and Core or due to a struggle between miners of similar hash power, it may make sense for users to wait for additional confirmations or convergence to avoid double spends.
faq.a7g: In Bitcoin Unlimited, we hope to eventually track ALL nontrivial forks and visually indicate when transactions have been confirmed on all forks, eliminating the possibility of a double spend.  This will allow users to use the bitcoin network normally during these periods.  However, since we do not believe that these periods will last long because they will cause a dramatic drop in miner revenue, it is not a priority.
